SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a literary text propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 6.

:ibox:Young as she was, she was a fearless rider, and at first, as we have seen, rather enjoyed the prospect of a tussle with Lady. But as the speed increased, Dorry found herself growing deaf, dumb and blind in the breathless race. Still, if she could only hold on, all would be well; she certainly could not consent to be conquered before ‚Äúthose boys.‚Äù
Based on the sentences, what inference can be made about Dorry?

A.Choice: Dorry is sick.

B.Choice: Dorry is angry.

C.Choice: Dorry is afraid.

D.Choice: Dorry is determined.

:ibox:He had heard Dorry scream, and somehow that scream made him and his pony one. Together, they flew over the field; with a steady, calm purpose, they cut across Lady‚Äôs course, and soon were at her side.

SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the claim that corvids are intelligent?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúFor starters, corvids are known to solve complex problems, use tools to obtain food, play in a social environment, cache food (or hide it for later), and recognize the faces of human friends and enemies.‚Äù (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: ‚ÄúCrows, ravens, and jays have found great success living among humans in cities and towns across the globe.‚Äù (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: ‚ÄúThe New Caledonia crow has a body-to-brain ratio similar to that of a small monkey, another animal with high intelligence.‚Äù (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: ‚Äú‚ÄòBirds and mammals are very different from each other,‚Äô says Cory. ‚ÄòThe brains are also built very differently. But animals from both groups seem to approach problems in the same manner and remember information in much the same ways.‚Äô‚Äù (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Determine an author‚Äôs point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
